questions.text: Identify the ethmoidal cells shown in the CT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

  • The CT scan shows air cells located anterior and superior to the nasolacrimal duct, marked by arrows.
  • These are Agger nasi cells, which are the most anterior ethmoidal air cells.
  • They are located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate and are important surgically, as they form the anterior boundary of the frontal recess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis: 

 

  • The largest and most constant anterior ethmoidal cell.
  • Lies posterior to the uncinate process and forms part of the lateral nasal wall.

 

 

Option B. Concha bullosa:

 

  • Pneumatization of the middle turbinate itself.
  • Seen as an air-filled cavity inside the turbinate, not as anterior ethmoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell:

 

  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cells, located along the floor of the orbit near the maxillary sinus roof.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

1. Microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent branching pattern on FFA

2. Hard exudates are found in outer plexiform layer 

3. Normal A:V ratio is 3:2 at the fundus 

4. IOC for best disease is EOG

  2. The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis.
  3. The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination is as follows: Rose Bengal → Lisssamine green →  Fluorescein

What does the given image represent?

A 27-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis is experiencing double vision. On examination, her eye movements are normal except for her right gaze where her left eye fails to adduct and her right eye shows nystagmus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 12 mm depth of invasion on biopsy. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to?

A 14-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his parents, who are worried about his reaction to their recent decision to divorce. Despite their efforts to be supportive and engage him, he has not expressed any feelings directly about the divorce. When the patient is evaluated alone, he shares that he feels his parents are angry with him, although he cannot think of any instances when they expressed any anger toward him. On examination, the patient appears sullen and reports his mood is "fine." This patient is most likely using which of the following defense mechanisms?

choices.text: Occurs due to a degenerative process
Seen as tiny round yellow-white opacities
Particles sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile

questions.text: All of the following are features of asteroid hyalosis except?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Particles sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except:
A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage 

 

  • Signs of Suprachoroidal hemorrhage include the following:
    • Anterior chamber shallowing
    • Loss of the red reflex
    • Increased IOP, with firming of the eye
    • Wrinkling and bulging of the posterior capsule
    • Extrusion of intraocular contents: spontaneous nuclear expression, iris prolapse, vitreous prolapse
  • Maculopathy is a common consequence of hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.
  • Excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery is the most common cause of hypotonic maculopathy.
  • Other causes include trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony, usually bilateral, include dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes with hyperglycaemia, uraemia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

questions.text: What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grade 2 

 

The image shows a retracted tympanic membrane with the pars tensa pulled inward and the handle of malleus clearly visible, but not adherent to the promontory. This corresponds to Sade’s classification of tympanic membrane retraction.

 

Sade’s Classification of Retraction Pockets:

 

  • Grade 1: Mild retraction, tympanic membrane touches incus or stapes but not fixed.
  • Grade 2: Retraction touches the incus or stapes but not adherent to the promontory. (Seen in this case)
  • Grade 3: Tympanic membrane adherent to the promontory but not fixed.
  • Grade 4: Tympanic membrane completely plastered onto the promontory and immobile.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with progressive proptosis of his right eye. The proptosis increases on bending forward and is compressible. No thrill or bruit was present. MRI is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:

A 36-year-old woman was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and has been taking lithium for the past 5 years. She is currently in remission. However, she now presented to the OPD with worsening depression, fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, renal colic, and bone pain. Which of the following tests would most likely reveal the underlying cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Distortion of corneal reflex at center

questions.text: In Keratoconus all are seen except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hypermetropic refractive error found

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with complaints of recurrent periods of prolonged sleep with intervening periods of normal sleep. He says that he sleeps up to 20 hours at a time and has increased appetite and libido. He does not have any pre-existing disorder and is not on any medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following will not be associated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abnormal SISI score

 

The MRI image shows an enhancing mass at the cerebellopontine angle, typical for vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). In this condition:

 

  • Abnormal stapedial reflex decay, roll over phenomenon (reduced speech discrimination at higher volumes), and Hitzelberger sign (numbness over the posterior auricle) can all be seen due to involvement of cranial nerves VII and VIII.
  • Abnormal SISI (Short Increment Sensitivity Index) score indicates cochlear (sensory) hearing loss—not neural. Vestibular schwannoma causes retrocochlear (neural) hearing loss, in which SISI is typically normal.

 

Thus, the correct answer is Abnormal SISI score.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormal stapedial (acoustic) reflex decay:

 

  • In retrocochlear lesions, like vestibular schwannoma, the stapedius reflex may be absent or show rapid decay.
  • This occurs because the neural pathways for the reflex are affected, preventing sustained contraction of the stapedius muscle.
  • Detecting abnormal reflex decay is a useful screening tool for retrocochlear pathology.

 

Option B. Roll over phenomenon:

 

  • This refers to a paradoxical drop in speech discrimination scores as the presentation intensity increases.
  • Seen in neural (retrocochlear) hearing loss, because damaged nerves can't process loud signals efficiently.
  • It helps differentiate neural from cochlear (sensory) causes of hearing loss.

 

Option D. Hitzelberger sign:

 

  • This is numbness or decreased sensation over the posterior superior external auditory canal.
  • It occurs due to early involvement of the sensory fibers of the facial nerve by the tumor.
  • Hitzelberger sign suggests involvement of cranial nerve VII, supporting the diagnosis of vestibular schwannoma.

questions.text: A medical student just finished the NEET-PG exam and is anxious about her performance. She is especially unnerved when fellow students talk about the difficulty of the exam and discuss their answers to certain questions. The student decides not to think about the exam until her score arrives because "worrying isn't going to change the result." She is delighted when she receives a top rank several weeks later. Before receiving the result, the student exhibited which of the following defense mechanisms?

A 7-year-old child was evaluated for night blindness. Ophthalmoscopy showed atrophic changes in the choroid, retina, and pigment epithelium. Urine and plasma ornithine levels were elevated. Defective catabolism of which of the following amino acids led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arginine

 

The described condition is Gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina, a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by:

 

  • Progressive chorioretinal degeneration (night blindness → visual field constriction → eventual blindness)
  • Elevated plasma and urinary ornithine levels

 

This occurs due to a defect in the enzyme ornithine aminotransferase (OAT), which is essential for ornithine catabolism (a step in arginine metabolism).

 

Normal Pathway:

 

Arginine → (via arginase) → Ornithine → (via ornithine aminotransferase) → Glutamate semialdehyde → Glutamate / Proline

 

When ornithine aminotransferase is deficient, ornithine cannot be converted further → accumulates in blood and urine → toxic to retinal pigment epithelium and choroid → causes gyrate atrophy and night blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histidine: Defects cause histidinemia, associated with speech and developmental delay, not ocular changes.

 

Option B. Glycine: Glycine metabolism defects cause nonketotic hyperglycinemia (lethargy, hypotonia, seizures, profound developmental delay in survivors).

 

Option C. Serine: Serine metabolism defects affect neurological development, unrelated to chorio-retinal tissue.

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient with low frustration tolerance
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred?
questions.solution: Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with epistaxis since 5 days. MRI is done which is shown below. Identify the Radkowski stage of the tumor in this case.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage III

 

The MRI shows a large nasopharyngeal mass extending into the infratemporal fossa and intracranial cavity. This is typical of an advanced juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) of stage III.

 

Radkowski staging system for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma:

 

  • Stage IA: Tumor limited to the nose and nasopharyngeal cavity.
  • Stage IB: Extension into ≥1 paranasal sinus.
  • Stage IIA: Minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Stage IIB: Full occupation of the pterygopalatine fossa, bowing of the posterior wall of maxilla, involvement of sphenoid sinus.
  • Stage IIC: Extension into the infratemporal fossa or orbit (without intracranial extension).
  • Stage IIIA: Intracranial extradural spread.
  • Stage IIIB: Intracranial intradural spread.

 

In This Case:

 

  • The MRI shows intracranial extension of the tumor → by definition = Stage III.
  • Since there is clear intracranial involvement, this rules out Stage IIA, IIB, or IIC.

questions.text: A psychologist gives the following card to a patient and asks him to describe what he sees. Which of the following is being assessed here?
The following device is used for all of the following indications except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Corneal tattooing

 

The image shows a stenopaic slit (stenopaic disc) — a diagnostic ophthalmic device consisting of a black circular disc with a narrow slit in the center.


The slit allows light to pass only through a specific meridian of the eye, helping to evaluate refractive errors.

 

This device is not used for corneal tattooing, which involves pigmentation of the cornea for cosmetic or optical purposes.

 

Hence, option C is the correct answer (the exception).

 

  • Corneal tattooing (keratopigmentation) is a surgical cosmetic procedure to hide corneal scars or leukomas or to reduce glare in aniridia.

 

Uses pigments or dyes, not optical devices like the stenopaic slit

 

Uses of the Stenopaic Slit

questions.text: Which of the following is the safety muscle of larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

The safety muscle of the larynx is the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, which is responsible for abducting (opening) the vocal cords and thus maintaining a patent airway. In the image, the region labeled "C" corresponds to the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

 

  • This muscle is crucial as its bilateral paralysis can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. It is termed the "safety muscle" of the larynx for this reason.

 

Other Options:

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the OPD for follow-up of hypertension. At his last appointment, he revealed that he had increased his intake of cans of beer from 3 to 6 cans daily due to stress at work. The physician advised him to seek help for his alcohol use because it could be causing his elevated blood pressure and has many negative health risks. The patient now tells the physician, "I thought about what you said. I know my alcohol use has gotten out of hand and is affecting my health. My wife and daughter also say that I need to quit. I have made an appointment with a counselor to talk about my options." Which of the following best describes this patient's stage of behavioral change?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preparation

 

In the preparation stage of the transtheoretical model of behavior change, the individual recognizes the problem, intends to take action soon, and often begins making small steps toward change. In this case, the patient admits that his drinking is a problem, acknowledges the health impact, accepts family concern, and has already scheduled an appointment with a counselor. This shows he is preparing actively to quit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Action: The action stage involves overt behavior change, such as the patient already quitting alcohol or reducing intake. In this scenario, he has not yet stopped drinking, so he has not reached the action stage.

 

Option B. Contemplation: In this stage, the patient recognizes there may be a problem and considers change but has not committed or made concrete steps. An example would be a patient saying, “I know drinking might not be good for me, but I’m not sure I’m ready to stop.” Our patient has gone beyond this by taking a specific step toward change.

 

Option C. Precontemplation: In this stage, the patient denies having a problem and does not intend to change. For example, a patient might say, “My drinking is not a problem; I can handle it.” The man in this vignette clearly acknowledges his alcohol use is harmful, so this stage does not fit.

questions.text: 35-year-old man was hospitalized for a psychotic episode in which he heard voices of God and the devil and believed that his family was plotting to kill him. He improved rapidly with medication therapy and was discharged. Three weeks later, the patient comes to the emergency department due to generalized muscle stiffness and shaking of his right hand. On mental status examination, he is alert and oriented with mild paranoia but no auditory hallucinations. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's current symptoms?

A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes was brought to the OPD by his wife after he began talking about aliens who were trying to steal his soul. He often stops talking mid-sentence and frequently scans the room for aliens. His wife reported he started expressing these ideas a few months ago, but they have become more severe and he had become isolated from his peers. Which of the following drugs should not be used in this patient?
Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataract.
It refers to a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea (endothelium), typically seen in pigment dispersion syndrome or pigmentary glaucoma, not in cataracts.

 

The pigment originates from the posterior surface of the iris and gets deposited on the corneal endothelium due to aqueous convection currents.

 

Thus, while it’s an ophthalmic finding, it is unrelated to complicated cataract formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: Seen in complicated cataracts, where the lens shows multicolored reflexes when illuminated due to changes in refractive index of degenerating lens fibers. This iridescent appearance is a hallmark of chronic inflammatory cataract.

 

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Complicated cataract develops secondary to chronic intraocular inflammation, especially anterior uveitis, iridocyclitis, or retinitis. Inflammation alters lens metabolism leading to opacification — hence, this is a classic cause.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: Refers to irregular, grayish-white opacities in the posterior subcapsular region of the lens — characteristic of complicated cataract due to inflammatory deposits resembling “bread crumbs.”

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of branch and parent nerve:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infratrochlear-Maxillary Nerve

 

  • The infratrochlear nerve is actually a branch of the nasociliary nerve, which itself is a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of trigeminal nerve.
  • The option incorrectly pairs infratrochlear with the maxillary nerve (V2), which has no role in this branch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraorbital – Frontal Nerve: Correct. The frontal nerve (V1) divides into supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves.

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal – Nasociliary Nerve: Correct. The nasociliary nerve (V1) gives off anterior and posterior ethmoidal nerves.

 

Option D. Ciliary – Nasociliary Nerve: Correct. Long ciliary nerves are branches of the nasociliary nerve (V1). Short ciliary nerves arise from the ciliary ganglion (parasympathetic + sympathetic + sensory roots, including nasociliary).

choices.text: Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?

questions.text: SCOFF QUESTIONS includes all of the following except?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Is your weight classified as Obese?

questions.text: Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to worsening anxiety and insomnia over the past 3 months. She says, "I'm really worried that something is wrong with me. I was never a particularly anxious person, but now I feel anxious all the time. Sometimes I feel panicky for no reason; my heart races and I break out in a sweat. The only benefit is that I have lost 5 pounds (2.3 kg) without even trying." Blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg and pulse is 112/min. On physical examination, the patient is restless and has warm, moist skin and mild hand tremor bilaterally. Mental status examination is notable for a frightened stare, anxious mood, and rapid speech. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. MRI shows the following changes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

 

  • The patient has recurrent episodes of vision loss in both eyes, which improve with steroids.
  • MRI changes (classically long-segment involvement in the spinal cord here but can show optic nerve inflammation also) support demyelinating pathology.

  • Neuromyelitis optica (Devic’s disease) is characterized by:

    • Severe, recurrent optic neuritis → visual loss.
    • Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (spinal cord lesions extending ≥3 vertebral segments).
    • Strong association with anti-AQP4 (aquaporin-4) antibodies.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spastic quadriplegia: Genetic disorder presenting in childhood with progressive spasticity, not episodic visual loss.

 

Option B. Subacute combined degeneration: Seen in Vitamin B12 deficiency. Presents with posterior column (loss of vibration & proprioception) and corticospinal tract involvement, not optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: Also causes optic neuritis, but MS usually has short-segment spinal lesions on MRI, whereas NMO shows long-segment cord lesions with more severe optic nerve involvement.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Crus commune is formed by the union of superior and posterior semicircular canal.
  2. Temperatures used in bithermal caloric test are 32 and 46 degrees Celsius.
  3. Pars flaccida is weaker due to absence of mucosal layer
  4. Incus long process has got no muscular attachments
The following curve may be seen with the following drugs except

A 55-year-old male presents with dizziness and involuntary eye movements. Examination reveals non-fatiguable nystagmus that changes direction with gaze and is not suppressed by visual fixation. There are no significant auditory symptoms. What is the most likely cause of his nystagmus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brainstem stroke

 

This patient has features of central vertigo rather than peripheral.

 

  • Non-fatiguable nystagmus → Central (peripheral nystagmus fatigues with repeated testing, eg. in BPPV).
  • Direction-changing with gaze → Central (peripheral is unidirectional).
  • Not suppressed by visual fixation → Central (peripheral nystagmus decreases when patient fixates).
  • No auditory symptoms → Suggests it is not an inner ear (peripheral) disorder, which usually has hearing loss, tinnitus, or ear fullness.

 

Thus, the most likely cause = brainstem stroke (central vestibular lesion).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV):

 

  • Vertigo triggered by positional changes, lasts seconds.
  • Nystagmus is fatiguable, unidirectional, suppressed by fixation.
  • Not fitting here.

 

Option B. Vestibular neuritis:

 

  • Sudden severe vertigo without hearing loss.
  • Nystagmus is unidirectional and suppressed by fixation.
  • Not direction-changing.

 

Option D. Ménière’s disease:

 

  • Triad: episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus.
  • Always has auditory symptoms, absent here.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bezold abscess

 

  • Bezold’s abscess:
    • Occurs when pus from mastoiditis escapes through the medial aspect of mastoid tip into the sternocleidomastoid sheath.
    • Presents as deep neck abscess with neck swelling, fever, and pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-auricular abscess: Localized abscess in front of the ear, not related to mastoid tip.

 

Option C. Luc abscess: Subperiosteal abscess in children, due to infection breaking through outer cortex of mastoid → swelling above ear, without bone destruction.

 

Option D. Citelli’s abscess: Pus spreads posteriorly through mastoid emissary vein → occipital/retroauricular swelling.

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed
Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps

questions.text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed

 

Option A. Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed: This is the classic test for immediate memory. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of digits (usually ranging from 5 to 9 numbers), and it tests the capacity of one's immediate memory.

 

Option B. Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps: This tests concentration.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 13.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?
What is the action of the muscle supplied by the structure marked A. in the image?

A 47-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of sudden painless visual loss in his right eye. The patient describes the loss of vision as a veil covering the visual field. He is slightly myopic and had a successful cataract extraction with intraocular lens implantation 3 years ago. The examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Topical pilocarpine and Nd:YAG 532nm laser capsulotomy
Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Femtosecond laser Iridotomy
Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG 1064nm laser Iridotomy

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman attends the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. She says that her right eye is painful and red. Vision is reduced. She is longsighted and wears glasses for near and distance vision. She is generally fit. There is no family history of medical problems. On examination the emergency doctor finds the vision to be reduced to counting fingers in the right eye. The eye is red, the cornea appears cloudy and edematous, and the pupil is oval and dilated on the affected side. No view of the fundus is obtained. What are the immediate and definitive treatment options?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG 1064nm laser Iridotomy

questions.text:
Arrange in order of increasing hearing loss? 

 

  1. EAC obstruction
  2. Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane 
  3. Disrupted ossicular chain and disrupted tympanic membrane 
  4. Complete stapes footplate fixation

A 33-year-old man is hospitalized after neighbors called the police to report that he has been singing loudly and playing the piano "nonstop" all day and night for the last month. The patient says his mood is "terrific," claims he is related to the President, and hears voices telling him he is going to be a famous entertainer.  He has a history of 9 psychiatric hospitalizations starting at age 22 for mood and psychotic symptoms. In between hospitalizations, the patient has heard voices for several months commenting on his appearance and has believed that secret cameras have been monitoring him, but he has had no mood symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz, while Rinne positive at 512 and 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap?

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text:

A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs associated with an irresistible urge to move the legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. Which of the following drugs is considered as the drug of choice in treating her condition?

  3. Prussack space is the most common site for recurrent disease

  1. BERA
  2. OAE
  3. PTA
  4. Tympanometry
A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?

A male patient with a history of hypermature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:
Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

choices.text: It is an antagonist at a4ß2 receptor
It interacts with nicotinic ACh receptors
Its use is associated with suicidal tendencies
It is useful in decreasing craving

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding varenicline?
questions.solution: Ans. A) It is an antagonist at a4ß2 receptor

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy 

 

  • The clinical presentation:
    • Normal Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) → suggests peripheral hearing sensitivity is intact.
    • BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) discrepancy with absent mid-latency and cortical responses → indicates that although sound is detected, the neural transmission of auditory signals to and within the brainstem/cortex is impaired.
    • The patient can hear sounds but cannot understand speech properly (poor speech discrimination).

 

This pattern is characteristic of Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD).

 

  • In ANSD, the outer hair cell function is normal (so otoacoustic emissions and PTA may be preserved).
  • But there is abnormal/absent neural conduction along the auditory nerve and brainstem pathways → leading to absent/abnormal BERA, middle latency, and cortical responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia:

 

  • Complete absence of inner ear structures (rare congenital anomaly).
  • Would cause profound sensorineural hearing loss with abnormal PTA, not normal results.

 

Option C. Malingering:

 

  • In malingering, patients feign hearing loss.
  • Here, PTA is normal but objective tests (BERA, cortical responses) are absent, which wouldn’t be the case in malingering.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis:

 

  • Causes progressive conductive or mixed hearing loss due to stapes fixation and cochlear involvement.
  • PTA would show conductive loss, not normal hearing with absent neural responses.

choices.text: No change observed in both eyes

questions.text: What would you expect to see on the instillation of 1% hydroxyamphetamine into both the eyes of a patient with right-sided postganglionic Horner syndrome?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Only left eye dilates

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a checkup. Her husband died 5 months ago in a biking accident, which she witnessed. She has little appetite, resulting in weight loss of 3.17 kg, and tends to wake up two hours before her alarm clock rings.  She avoids cycling, a hobby she shared with her husband, but continues to volunteer at a children's hospital. The patient has no nightmares or suicidal thoughts. During the visit, she tears up intermittently but smiles when sharing a memory of a vacation she took with her husband. Which of the following is the best explanation for this patient's condition?
Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?

A mother brings her 4-year-old boy with complaints of bedwetting. On asking history, she informs that he does about 3 to 4 times per week. On further evaluation, he has a normal urine stream, daytime urine continence, and no history of UTIs. His physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Level VI lymph nodes

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to a family therapist by his wife following a violent outburst in which he nearly injured her. They were having what seemed like a minor argument over a miscommunication about her being late when he suddenly flew into a rage, started shouting, and threw several plates against the wall. His wife is now threatening to leave him because similar episodes keep happening despite his promise to control his anger. The patient is remorseful and says, "I have been getting into trouble because of my temper since high school. Once I get angry, I feel out of control and it's impossible to stop." He drinks beer and uses cannabis to relax approximately 2-3 times a month. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: External hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland
Meibomian gland is a modified apocrine gland
Internal hordeolum is an acute suppurative inflammation of meibomian gland
Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland

questions.text: Which of the following is false:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Meibomian gland is a modified apocrine gland

questions.text: A young woman presents with bilateral stuffy nose for the past 3 months. She reports relief for 2-3 hours after using oxymetazoline spray, but the congestion worsens soon after, requiring more frequent use. Which of the following best explains this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rebound congestion

 

Let’s see Mechanism of Action of Nasal Decongestants

  • Drugs like oxymetazoline, xylometazoline, phenylephrine are topical nasal decongestants.
  • They are alpha-adrenergic agonists → cause vasoconstriction of nasal mucosal vessels → shrinkage of mucosa → rapid relief of nasal obstruction.

 

What happens with prolonged use:

 

  • If used beyond 3–5 days, a paradoxical effect develops:

 

1. Tachyphylaxis:

 

  • Continuous stimulation of alpha-receptors leads to receptor desensitization and downregulation.
  • Each subsequent dose produces less effect (patient feels drug “stops working”).

 

2. Rebound Congestion (Rhinitis medicamentosa):

 

  • After the drug wears off, the blood vessels dilate excessively due to loss of sympathetic tone + receptor exhaustion.
  • Leads to severe nasal congestion worse than baseline.
  • Patient uses the spray more frequently to relieve this, causing a vicious cycle of dependence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Development of Tolerance: Decreased efficacy with repeated use, but here symptoms worsen after use, not reduced effect.

 

Option C. Irritation from the nasal spray: Would cause burning/itching in locally applied area, not rebound congestion.

 

Option D. Medication-induced rhinosinusitis: No features of sinus infection (discharge, fever, pain).

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing, following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of this condition?
CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging?

Which of these is a true statement? 

 

  1. Ferry’s Line - corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs 
  2. Stockers Line - Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of pterygium 
  3. Hudson-Stahli line - visible all around the base of cone in Keratoconus 
  4. Fleischer’s ring - Horizontal corneal epithelial iron line’ at the inferior one third of cornea due to aging
  5. Coat’s white ring - A form of iron deposit at the level of Bowman’s layer of cornea
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 5

 

True Statements:

 

1. Ferry’s Line:


A corneal epithelial iron deposition line that forms at the edge of filtering blebs following glaucoma filtering surgery.
It is due to tear film stagnation and iron deposition from tears.
Seen as a fine brownish line adjacent to the surgical bleb.

 

 

2. Stocker’s Line:


An iron line located at the advancing edge of a pterygium, deposited beneath the corneal epithelium.


Occurs due to tear pooling and chronic irritation caused by the pterygium head.
 

It indicates a slowly progressive pterygium.

 

 

5. Coats’ White Ring:


Appears as a small, oval or circular superficial white opacity at the level of Bowman’s membrane.


It represents iron and fibrous tissue deposition secondary to a healed metallic foreign body injury.


It is a residual, non-progressive lesion and does not affect vision.

 

 

False Statements:

 

3. Hudson–Stähli Line:
 

A horizontal iron line seen in the lower third of the cornea, usually in elderly individuals.
 

It results from tear pooling near the lower lid margin.
 

It is not associated with keratoconus and is unrelated to the cone base.

 

 

4. Fleischer’s Ring:


An iron deposition ring surrounding the base of the cone in keratoconus, best seen with cobalt blue light.
 

It forms due to tear stagnation at the cone margin.
 

It is not a horizontal aging line, which differentiates it from Hudson–Stähli line.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Ideal time to do electroneurography studies in a patient with facial nerve injury will be 1 week to 3 weeks following injury. 
  2. Tonsillolingual sulcus is the ENT surgeon’s graveyard. 
  3. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  4. The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Ideal time to do electroneurography studies in a patient with facial nerve injury will be 1 week to 3 weeks following injury:

 

  • Correct. Electroneurography (ENoG) measures degeneration of facial nerve fibers.
  • Degeneration begins after 72 hours and peaks within 21 days.
  • Hence, best time = between 1 and 3 weeks post-injury.

 

Statement 2. Tonsillolingual sulcus is the ENT surgeon’s graveyard:

 

  • Correct. The tonsillolingual sulcus (area between tonsil and tongue base) is dangerous during tonsillectomy.
  • Houses important structures: lingual artery (close), glossopharyngeal nerve → risk of fatal bleeding and nerve injury.

 

Statement 3. Outer hair cells are in 3–4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells:

 

  • Correct. Outer hair cells (OHCs): arranged in 3–4 rows, act as cochlear amplifiers, improving sensitivity and frequency selectivity.
  • Inner hair cells (IHCs): arranged in a single row, function as true sensory receptors sending signals via auditory nerve.

 

Statement 4. The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively.

 

  • Correct. These fracture classifications are important in septal surgery and trauma assessment:
  • Chevallet’s fracture → vertical fracture.
  • Jarjaway’s fracture → horizontal fracture.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with leukocoria in the left eye. The CT is shown below. The most likely mutated gene is on the same chromosome as which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA2

 

The image shows a CT orbit/brain with calcified intraocular mass in a child presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) — classic for retinoblastoma.

 

Now, relating to the question:

 

They ask:

 

“The most likely mutated gene is on the same chromosome as which of the following genes?”

 

The RB1 gene is located on chromosome 13q14,
and the BRCA2 gene is also located on chromosome 13q12.3.

 

Genetic basis:

 

  • Caused by mutation of the RB1 gene (a tumor suppressor gene)
  • Chromosomal location: 13q14

 

Loss of both RB1 alleles (Knudson’s "two-hit" hypothesis) → loss of cell cycle control at G1-S checkpoint, leading to uncontrolled proliferation of retinal cells.

 

Key points:

 

Retinoblastoma

 

  • Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children
  • Presentation: Leukocoria, strabismus, proptosis, or orbital mass
  • CT finding: Intraocular calcification (diagnostic hallmark)

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

 

  1. The scala vestibuli is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery
  2. Pars superior gives rise to semicircular canals and utricle
  3. The best stain to increase sensitivity of detecting atypia during is Toluidine blue. 
  4. Ostmann’s pad of fat is seen at lateral semicircular canal
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 4

 

Statement 1. The scala vestibuli is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery

 

  •  Incorrect.
  • In cochlear implant surgery, the scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode insertion (via round window or cochleostomy).
  • Scala vestibuli is avoided because insertion there risks more trauma and poor stimulation.

 

Statement 4. Ostmann’s pad of fat is seen at lateral semicircular canal

 

  •  Incorrect.
  • Ostmann’s pad of fat is actually located near the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, helping maintain tubal closure.
  • It is not related to the lateral semicircular canal.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2. Pars superior gives rise to semicircular canals and utricle

 

  •  Correct.
  • Embryology: The otic vesicle (otocyst) divides into pars superior (→ semicircular canals + utricle) and pars inferior (→ cochlea + saccule).

 

Statement 3. The best stain to increase sensitivity of detecting atypia during is Toluidine blue

 

  •  Correct.
  • Toluidine blue is used as a vital stain in oral premalignant and malignant lesions, increasing sensitivity for detecting epithelial atypia/dysplasia.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lorazepam + thiamine followed by 5% dextrose

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
  2. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland
  3. Sturge-Weber syndrome is associated with congenital glaucoma. 
  4. Always use eye drops 15min before eye ointment.

Sequentially arrange the following structures that are involved in the production & conduction of otoacoustic emissions. 

 

  1. Outer hair cells
  2. Basilar membrane
  3. Oval window
  4. Perilymph
  5. Ossicles
  6. Tympanic membrane

A patient presented with foreign body sensation, redness, and excessive watering from the right eye for 15 days after a twig brushed against his eye. Examination is shown below. Which among the following is the appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below.

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient.
questions.solution: Ans. C) Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for worsening restlessness over the past several days. Three weeks ago, he was started on trifluoperazine for the treatment of schizophrenia. He reports that, since then, he has often felt compelled to pace around his house and is unable to sit or stand still. He is switched to an alternative antipsychotic medication. Four weeks later, the patient reports improvement of his symptoms but says that he has developed increased drowsiness, blurred vision, and dry mouth. The patient was most likely switched to which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chlorpromazine

 

This patient initially developed akathisia (a form of extrapyramidal symptom characterized by restlessness and inability to sit still) after being started on trifluoperazine, a high-potency typical antipsychotic. To manage this, he was switched to another drug. After the switch, he developed anticholinergic side effects such as sedation, blurred vision, and dry mouth, which are characteristic of low-potency typical antipsychotics like chlorpromazine and thioridazine. Hence, chlorpromazine is the most likely agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: This is a high-potency typical antipsychotic, similar to trifluoperazine. It carries a high risk of extrapyramidal side effects (akathisia, dystonia, parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia), not sedation and anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Option C. Trimipramine: This is a tricyclic antidepressant, not an antipsychotic. It is not used for schizophrenia and would not be the correct substitution for trifluoperazine.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: This is an atypical antipsychotic with partial dopamine agonist activity. It has fewer extrapyramidal side effects but does not cause significant anticholinergic symptoms such as sedation and blurred vision.

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

choices.text: Limbal girdle of Vogt: Corneal opacity that occurs in an arc concentric pattern

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Vogt triad-POAG

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient comes with complaints of a bilateral, non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality. She describes it as wearing a tight cap. She has no nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia. She also gives a history that she has had similar headaches for about 10 days in the past month. All the following treatment methods can be used in this patient, except:

A 6-month-old child is brought to the clinic with a common cold and the parents give a history of stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. On examination, you notice that he has biphasic stridor. What is the most probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital subglottic stenosis

 

  • The child has stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions since shortly after birth → strongly suggests a congenital cause rather than an acquired one.
  • Biphasic stridor (occurring during both inspiration and expiration) is a hallmark of fixed airway obstruction at the subglottic or glottic level.
  • Congenital subglottic stenosis = narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords (subglottis).
    • It is the third most common congenital airway anomaly after laryngomalacia and vocal cord paralysis.
    • Presents with biphasic stridor soon after birth, worsens with URTI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia:

 

  • Most common cause of congenital stridor.
  • But stridor is typically inspiratory (not biphasic).
  • Improves with prone position, worse in supine.

 

Option B. Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis)

 

  • Viral illness, acute onset after a few months of age.
  • Stridor is inspiratory, associated with barking cough and fever.
  • Not present since birth.

 

Option C. Respiratory papillomatosis:

 

  • Caused by HPV (types 6, 11).
  • Presents later (2–5 years), not immediately after birth.
  • Causes progressive hoarseness and stridor, not neonatal biphasic stridor.

 

Key Rule of Thumb:

 

  • Inspiratory stridor → supraglottic/glottic obstruction
  • Expiratory stridor → intrathoracic obstruction below subglottis towards distally.
  • Biphasic stridor → fixed obstruction at glottis or subglottis

questions.text: A patient with 1.5D myopia undergoes streak retinoscopy. The patient is seated one meter from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Movement against the plane

choices.text: Bowman's membrane ends peripherally as Schwalbe's ring
Consists of Superficial cells which have microvilli

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Bowman's membrane ends peripherally as Schwalbe's ring

questions.text: Audiogram of a 6 year old child is given. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents with generalized body aches, fatigue, and anxiety for the past 4 months, but her sleep is not affected due to pain. On examination, increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences are noted. Laboratory and radiological investigations were normal. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this patient?

Identify the correct statements about pediatric airway:

 

  1. Epiglottis moves up during swallowing 
  2. They can suckle and breathe at the same time 
  3. Larynx opposite C3-C6
  4. Narrowest portion is at the level of cricoid cartilage 
  5. Epiglottis is shorter and wider
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Epiglottis moves up during swallowing: Correct. In infants and children, the epiglottis is relatively high and helps in preventing aspiration. During swallowing, it elevates to protect the airway from food entry.

 

Statement 2. They can suckle and breathe at the same time: Correct. Infants are considered “obligate nasal breathers” up to around 6 months. The high position of the larynx allows them to breathe while suckling.

 

Statement 4. Narrowest portion is at the level of cricoid cartilage: Correct. In pediatrics (especially under 5 years), the airway is funnel-shaped, and the cricoid cartilage is the narrowest part, unlike in adults where it is the vocal cords.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. Larynx opposite C3–C6: Incorrect. In infants, the larynx is higher, usually opposite C2–C3. It descends gradually to adult level (C5–C6).

 

Statement 5. Epiglottis is shorter and wider: Incorrect. Pediatric epiglottis is actually longer, narrower, and more omega-shaped (floppy) compared to adults.

questions.text: A patient with narcolepsy has been prescribed tiprolisant. How does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H3 receptor inverse agonism

 

Tiprolisant (Pitolisant) is a histamine H₃ receptor inverse agonist/antagonist used in the treatment of narcolepsy with or without cataplexy.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • The H₃ receptor is an autoreceptor located on histaminergic neurons in the brain.
  • When activated, it inhibits histamine release and decreases the activity of other wake-promoting neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, acetylcholine).
  • Tiprolisant, by acting as an inverse agonist (functionally opposite of an agonist), blocks and reduces the inhibitory effect of these H₃ autoreceptors.
  • This leads to increased histamine release and enhanced activity of wake-promoting neurotransmitter systems, thereby improving wakefulness and alertness in narcoleptic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H₁ receptor agonism: H₁ receptors mediate allergic and inflammatory responses; agonists would not have CNS wake-promoting effects.

 

Option B. H₁ receptor inverse agonism: This is the mechanism of antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine), which cause sedation, not wakefulness.

 

Option C. H₃ receptor agonism: Would further inhibit histamine release, worsening sleepiness — opposite of the desired effect in narcolepsy.

choices.text: Inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal
Superior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal
Inferior border of infraorbital rim and inferior border of external auditory canal
Superior border of infraorbital rim and inferior border of external auditory canal

questions.text: Identify the correct plane of Frankfurt horizontal plane:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal

 

  • The Frankfurt Horizontal Plane (FHP) is a standard anatomical reference plane used in anthropology, orthodontics, and radiology.
  • It is defined by a line joining:
    • Inferior border of the infraorbital rim (orbitale) → lowest point on the infraorbital margin.
    • Superior border of the external auditory canal (porion) → uppermost point on the ear canal opening.
  • This plane represents the natural head position and is used as a baseline in cephalometry and skull measurements.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except

Arrange in correct order of cervical VEMP:

 

  1. Saccule 
  2. Utricle
  3. Superior vestibular nerve
  4. Inferior vestibular nerve
  5. Vestibular nucleus 
  6. SCM 
  7. MLF
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-4-5-6

 

The cervical Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential (cVEMP) is a reflex pathway that tests saccular and inferior vestibular nerve function, recorded from the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle.

 

The correct pathway is:

 

1. Saccule: origin of the reflex, sensitive to sound.

 

4. Inferior vestibular nerve: carries impulses from the saccule.

 

5. Vestibular nucleus: integration center in the brainstem.

 

6. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: inhibitory reflex recorded here.

 

Thus, the correct sequence = 1 → 4 → 5 → 6.

 

2. Cervical VEMP (cVEMP): Evaluates the saccule and inferior vestibular nerve by recording responses from the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle.

 

3. Ocular VEMP (oVEMP): Assesses the utricle and superior vestibular nerve by measuring responses from muscles near the C/L eyes (typically the inferior oblique).

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
Identify the syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duane's retraction syndrome type 1

 

The clinical image shows the typical findings of Duane's retraction syndrome type 1:

 

  • There is marked limitation of abduction (outward movement) of the affected eye.
  • Adduction (movement towards the nose) is relatively preserved, but there is narrowing of the palpebral fissure and retraction of the globe on attempted adduction.
  • These findings are most consistent with Duane's retraction syndrome type 1, which is the most common subtype and is characterized by limited abduction, retraction of the globe, and narrowing of the eyelid opening on adduction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare and is shown below. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her?
Which of the following will be difficult in the following case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

The chest X-ray provided shows a deviated trachea (pushed to the right side- shown by white arrows) and mediastinal shift, likely suggestive of right sided lung collapse.

 

In such cases, the landmarks of the trachea are distorted and displaced, which makes tracheostomy technically difficult because:

 

  • Trachea is not in its usual midline location.
  • Identifying tracheal rings is challenging.
  • There is increased risk of damaging adjacent structures (vessels, pleura, esophagus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal airway:

 

  • Placement of a supraglottic device (like LMA) is unaffected by tracheal deviation.
  • It is inserted blindly into the pharynx and seals around the laryngeal inlet, so deviation does not hinder.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation:

 

  • Intubation via direct laryngoscopy is not usually affected by tracheal deviation, since the trachea is still accessible through the glottis. The tube can still be advanced into the proximal part of trachea.

 

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy:

 

  • This is performed at the level of the cricothyroid membrane, which remains in the midline and is not significantly altered by intrathoracic pathology.
  • Thus, it is not technically difficult in this situation.
